emerging_technologies.name: AI-Driven Autonomous Development Environments
emerging_technologies.description: These environments autonomously handle software development tasks from conception to deployment, adapting to developer's coding style and project requirements.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Reduces human error in coding, increases productivity, but raises concerns about job displacement in software development.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: High initial investment, ethical considerations regarding AI's role in creative work, and regulatory compliance.

emerging_technologies.name: Neuralink 2.0
emerging_technologies.description: A refined brain-computer interface for seamless interaction with digital devices, enhancing cognitive capabilities and providing augmented reality experiences.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Potential for cognitive enhancement, but also raises privacy concerns, ethical issues around human augmentation, and potential for misuse.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Acceptance of invasive technology, ethical debates, and regulatory hurdles.

emerging_technologies.name: Quantum Blockchain
emerging_technologies.description: Integration of quantum computing with blockchain to enhance security, speed, and scalability of transactions.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could revolutionize secure transactions, but brings concerns about the centralization of power if quantum computing becomes too advanced.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Requires significant advances in quantum technology, high cost, and global consensus on blockchain standards.

emerging_technologies.name: Space-Based Solar Power
emerging_technologies.description: Collecting solar power in space where sunlight is uninterrupted and transmitting it back to Earth.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Provides a clean energy source, reduces dependency on terrestrial resources, but involves high initial costs and geopolitical space law issues.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Technological feasibility, international cooperation, and economic viability.

mainstream_technologies.name: AI-Powered Smart Cities
mainstream_technologies.description: Cities leveraging AI for traffic management, waste management, energy use optimization, and public safety.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Widely adopted in developed nations, with ongoing implementation in developing countries due to infrastructure readiness.

mainstream_technologies.name: Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) Level 4
mainstream_technologies.description: Vehicles capable of fully autonomous driving under specific conditions, significantly reducing human intervention.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Common in new vehicles, with full adoption in urban areas where infrastructure supports autonomous driving.

epoch_themes.description: AI becomes ubiquitous, deeply integrated into personal, professional, and societal operations.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Enhances efficiency but challenges include job displacement, privacy, and ethical AI use.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Global push towards AI ethics standards, AI education, and AI-driven policy making.

epoch_themes.description: Technology focuses on solving environmental challenges through innovative, sustainable solutions.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Promotes environmental stewardship, but requires significant investment and international collaboration.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Rise in green technology investments, carbon credit systems, and sustainable urban planning.
